title: Do You Hear What I Hear?
chief_complaint: I am hearing voices and radio or television signals through my hearing aids.

problem_summary.onset: Symptoms began recently, approximately 8 months after receiving new hearing aids.
problem_summary.course: Patient was initially pleased, then experienced weakness in aids at 4 months (resolved with cleaning), and now reports auditory hallucinations/interference at 8 months.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Hearing voices, radio signals; previously reported weak amplification.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Distracting and concerning; patient believes he is picking up radio signals.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to stop hearing voices/signals and ensure aids are working.

history.present_illness: Fitting of fourth pair of hearing aids. Patient is an experienced user (20 years).
history.prior_management: Previous hearing aids worn for 20 years.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.key_findings: Hearing aids met manufacturer specifications. Patient reported best hearing in 20 years.

history.present_illness: Patient returned for scheduled maintenance reporting dissatisfaction. Felt aids were providing less amplification than at dispensing.
history.medical_psych_history: Work environment involves high heat and humidity (summer months).

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.key_findings: Initial analysis confirmed aids were not functioning properly (reduced gain). After cleaning microphones/receivers and dehumidifying, performance returned to optimal.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.key_findings: Performance returned to optimal, consistent with baseline.

history.present_illness: Patient reports hearing aids are receiving radio/TV signals and he hears voices when wearing them. Voices are indiscernible, like a radio tuned between stations.
history.noise_exposure_history: Continued work in auto repair (dust, sweat, heat).
history.medical_psych_history: Denies history of hallucinations without aids.
history.prior_management: Uses desiccant jar (reminded at last visit).

tests.name: Physical Inspection
tests.key_findings: Accumulation of moisture and rust found in the battery compartments of both instruments.

tests.name: Listening Check
tests.key_findings: Auditorially very uncomfortable for the clinician; instruments were amplifying at an unusually high output level.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis (2-cc coupler)
tests.key_findings: Significant increase in gain and noise floor compared to baseline, consistent with moisture damage/internal component issues.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient is an experienced hearing aid user working in a high-humidity, dusty environment (automotive repair). While initial fitting was successful, subsequent visits revealed performance fluctuations driven by moisture ingress. The current presentation of 'hearing voices' correlates with electroacoustic findings of excessive gain and high internal noise floors caused by sweat and debris accumulation, rather than psychiatric auditory hallucinations.
counseling_points: The 'voices' you are hearing are actually internal noise and static caused by moisture damage in the hearing aid circuits, not radio signals.
Your work environment (heat, sweat, dust) is very harsh on hearing aids.
We need to send the aids for repair and apply a protective internal coating.
You must use an electronic dehumidifier every night, not just the standard jar.
notes_for_actor: Portray a rational person who is confused and slightly concerned about hearing voices, but convinced it is a technical issue (radio signals) rather than a mental health one.
Emphasize that you work in a hot garage and sweat a lot.
Express relief when told the 'voices' are just the hearing aids malfunctioning.
